qas.question: What is an annelid's brain in a ring around?

answers.text: in the peristomium or sometimes the first segment behind the peristomium

qas.question: What is an annelid's brain in a sphere around?

plausible_answers.text: in the peristomium or sometimes the first segment behind the peristomium

qas.question: What nerve cords are never fused in polychaetes?

context: The brain generally forms a ring round <a1_0><b5_0>the pharynx<b5_0/><a1_0/> (<a2_0>throat<a2_0/>), consisting of a pair of ganglia (<a0_0>local control centers<a0_0/>) above and in front of the pharynx, linked by nerve cords either side of the pharynx to another pair of ganglia just below and behind it. The brains of polychaetes are generally <a4_0><b7_0>in the prostomium<b7_0/><a4_0/>, while those of clitellates are <a3_0><b6_0>in the peristomium or sometimes the first segment behind the peristomium<b6_0/><a3_0/>. In some very mobile and active polychaetes the brain is enlarged and more complex, with visible hindbrain, midbrain and forebrain sections. The rest of <b8_0>the central nervous system<b8_0/> is generally "ladder-like", consisting of a pair of nerve cords that run through the bottom part of the body and have in each segment paired ganglia linked by a transverse connection. From each segmental ganglion a branching system of local nerves runs into the body wall and then encircles the body. However, in most polychaetes <b9_0>the two main nerve cords<b9_0/> are fused, and in the tube-dwelling genus Owenia the single nerve chord has no ganglia and is located in the epidermis.
